node.title: Hockey Backtracks on Plan to Eject Chinese Team From Olympics
node.alt: A hockey test event in Beijing in April. Assembling a competitive team has proved far more difficult for the 2022 Olympic host country.
node.description: Weeks after a top hockey official suggested quality concerns could see China’s men kicked out of the Beijing Games, the team’s participation was confirmed.
node.content: ["Ice hockey\u2019s governing body on Tuesday backtracked on plans to bar China\u2019s men\u2019s team from competing next year at the Beijing Olympics, a swift reversal that came only weeks after the hockey organization\u2019s president had raised concerns that China\u2019s team simply was not good enough to merit a place in the field.", "The organization\u2019s president, Luc Tardif, announced that China would remain in the Olympic tournament in a statement released at the end of a three-day meeting of the International Ice Hockey Federation in Zurich.", "\u201cTo be clear, the I.I.H.F. is not going to remove the Chinese team from the Olympic Games,\u201d Tardif said. \u201cThe status of the men\u2019s national team as a host nation participant in the Olympic ice hockey tournament was confirmed by congress and remains unchanged,\u201d a reference to an earlier vote to place the Chinese men in the field, a courtesy granted to nearly all Olympic host nations.", "It was Tardif, though, who had suggested in September that the poor quality of China\u2019s team might lead ice hockey officials to replace the squad in the Games. \u201cWatching a team being beaten, 15-0, is not good for anyone, not for China or for ice hockey,\u201d Tardif told Agence France-Presse. He said hockey needed to urgently consider a \u201cPlan B\u201d for the Olympics.", "His comments created a potentially embarrassing situation for hockey, Beijing 2022 organizers and, perhaps most important, the Chinese government. China\u2019s president, Xi Jinping, views the Beijing Games as an opportunity for the country to showcase its relative success in taming the coronavirus and to demonstrate its emergence as a global power.", "Still, the risk of Chinese humiliation rose this fall when the International Olympic Committee announced that it had reached an agreement with the National Hockey League over the release of players for the Games, ensuring that China\u2019s first-round opponents \u2014 the United States, Canada and Germany \u2014 would be stocked with some of the game\u2019s best talent.", "Concerns about China\u2019s performances are linked to a Chinese team that competes in Russia\u2019s Kontinental Hockey League. The team, Kunlun Red Star, is usually based in Beijing but relocated to a city close to Moscow during the coronavirus pandemic in order to play in the league\u2019s eastern division. It currently has the worst record in the 24-team league.", "Yet even as Tardif said China would remain in the Olympic tournament, the international federation said it was working with the Chinese Ice Hockey Association to schedule two games featuring players eligible to represent the national team \u201cin a joint effort to evaluate the status of the team\u2019s preparations for Beijing 2022.\u201d", "If the games can be arranged, the Chinese players would compete for Kunlun Red Star in two K.H.L. games, on Nov. 15 and 17. After those dates, the statement released Tuesday said, \u201cthe I.I.H.F. Council will reconvene to discuss the next steps forward.\u201d"]
